metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Nanalal Haridas

facts.text: Nanalal Haridas was the karta of a Hindu undivided family which was the beneficiary of 1842 shares in Cotton Export and Import Limited.
Shares held in names: 877 in Tribhuvandas Haridas, 815 in Nanalal Haridas, 150 in Nanalal Haridas and Tribhuvandas Haridas.
Company was one in which the public were substantially interested.

For assessment year 1949-50, Income-tax Officer applied s.23A of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 (pre-1955 amendment) and deemed undistributed income as dividend proportionate to 1842 shares, grossed up to Rs. 54,307/-, added to income of joint family.
Assessee family claimed deemed dividend should be assessed in hands of registered shareholders, not HUF.
Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's contention.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, by order dated February 15, 1957, allowed appeal following Bombay High Court in S.C. Cambatta v. CIT, directed deletion of deemed dividend from HUF income.

Commissioner of Income-tax moved Tribunal to refer question: 'Whether the dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- is to be assessed in the hands of the assessee, the Hindu undivided family?' Tribunal referred it.
Bombay High Court, by order dated September 25, 1957, answered in favour of assessee, holding deemed dividend not income of HUF as it could not be registered shareholder, reaffirming S.C. Cambatta.
High Court refused leave to appeal; Commissioner obtained special leave from Supreme Court.
Similar facts in Income-tax References Nos. 30 and 37 of 1957, disposed per leading judgment in No. 29 of 1957.

legal_issues.text: Whether the dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- deemed distributed under s.23A is to be assessed in the hands of the assessee Hindu undivided family or the registered shareholders.

petitioner_arguments.text: Shareholder in s.23A means beneficial owner (HUF), not just registered holder, to prevent avoidance of super-tax; narrow interpretation defeats purpose of section.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Object of s.23A; dictionary meaning of shareholder

petitioner_arguments.text: Legal fiction of deemed distribution must be carried to logical conclusion: dividend received by beneficial owner HUF.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principle of legal fiction in s.23A

respondent_arguments.text: Deemed dividend under s.23A to be included in income of registered shareholders; HUF not and cannot be registered shareholder.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Express terms of s.23A; S.C. Cambatta v. CIT

court_reasoning.text: S.23A in express terms requires proportionate share included in total income of 'shareholder'; does not mention beneficial owner; shareholder means registered in books of company, consistent with s.18(5) and Companies Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason why 'shareholder' in s.23A differs from s.18(5) or Companies Act.

court_reasoning.text: HUF as such cannot be registered shareholder or member; sub-ss.(3),(4) of s.23A refer to members.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fiction restricted to plain terms of statute; cannot extend to cure lacuna.

court_reasoning.text: Interpretation does not defeat purpose: applies to registered shareholders; legal fiction not to be extended beyond terms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question one of statutory interpretation only.

holdings.text: Deemed dividend under s.23A included in total income of registered shareholders, not beneficial owner HUF if not registered.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.C. Cambatta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Registered holders treated as shareholder under s.23A; s.23A procedural, not charging; no reference to beneficial ownership.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shree Shakti Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Shareholder' in s.18(5) means registered in company register.

precedents_cited.case_name: Howrah Trading Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Shareholder' in s.18(5) same as in Companies Act; no valid reason for different meaning.

precedents_cited.case_name: Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Nandlal Gandalal
precedents_cited.relevance: Position of HUF; question of interpretation, not partnership/Hindu law.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: S.23A deems undistributed income as dividend to shareholders (registered); followed by assessment; consistent meaning of shareholder.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Bombay High Court; deemed dividend income under s.23A not assessable in hands of HUF beneficiary but in registered shareholders; appeals dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Direction to delete deemed dividend from HUF income upheld.

key_quotes.text: The section in express terms says that the proportionate share of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of the shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income. The section does not talk of the beneficial owner of the share.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We see no reason why the expression shareholder in s.23A should not have the same meaning, namely, a shareholder registered in the books of the company.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Consistency with s.18(5) and Companies Act.

key_quotes.text: The fiction enacted by the Legislature must be restricted by the plain terms of the statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
